column2: Ammavila, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took Lariam during two different trips to Africa, a month-long trip and a three month trip a year later. I suffered from hallucinations, vivid dreams, and nightmares during which I sat bolt upright in my bed, screamed at the top of my lungs, yet didn't wake up. (My friends witnessed this, lucky them.) I had seizures. I physically attacked a friend who said she didn't have a light for my cigarette. (I was convinced that she was lying). I became so angry that my mind went red, I couldn't think, and I jumped her. I had to be pulled off her. I was in a manic state, couldn't sleep, grandiose thoughts, talking all the time.15 years later, and I still talk in my sleep and have night terrors. I wouldn't wish this drug on my worst enemy. If I had to take it again I fully believe that I would wind up killing myself or someone else. This drug is an instrument of torture. No wonder they use it on prisoners at Guantanamo Bay!

column9: I post this as a warning to anyone with any history of depression or other mental health issues.  I took this drug as a malaria preventative when I went abroad last year.  Mefloquin literally spun me into a mania that required extensive hospitalization abroad and upon my return for psychiatric issues.  I was hallucinating, couldn't sleep, had racing thoughts, tons of energy, was extremely emotional and out of my head.  Horrifying in every respect.  I missed two months of work.  I now know that I will never again take a quinolone-class antibiotic and have it listed as a drug allergy.

column2: Desert Fighter, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Was prescribed this medication for prophylaxis treatment.  Was on it for almost 3 months. First 3 - 4 weeks I experienced vivid but not overly troubleing dreams.  By 4th week I became very agressive and had difficulty sleeping.  After two months began to experience anxiety and paranoia (thought co workers were "out to get me"). At 9 weeks I experienced "night terrors" the night I took my dose.  Anxiety became worse and I started to feel alternating anger and depression.  The day of my last dose I felt like I was shot with methadrine for the entire day. I finally realized the symptoms were worst on days I took this medicine. I did not realize how badly this drug was effecting my disposition and behavior. After the last dose I sought out medical treatment and was switched to doxycycline and given ambien to aid in sleeping over the next week.  Have people around you who are aware of possible side effects if you are using this medication.
